title: Add REST API with Swagger for backend testing
description:
Implement a REST API layer to enable programmatic access and API-level testing of Homespun functionality.

## Architecture
- Keep Blazor components using @inject for direct service access (no change)
- Add thin API controllers that call existing services
- Add Swagger/OpenAPI documentation

## API Endpoints

### Projects
- GET /api/projects - List all projects
- GET /api/projects/{id} - Get project by ID
- POST /api/projects - Create project
- PUT /api/projects/{id} - Update project
- DELETE /api/projects/{id} - Delete project

### Pull Requests
- GET /api/projects/{id}/pull-requests - List PRs for project
- GET /api/pull-requests/{id} - Get PR by ID
- POST /api/pull-requests - Create PR
- PUT /api/pull-requests/{id} - Update PR
- POST /api/projects/{id}/sync - Sync PRs from GitHub

### Git Worktrees
- GET /api/worktrees - List worktrees
- POST /api/worktrees - Create worktree
- DELETE /api/worktrees/{path} - Delete worktree

### Claude Sessions
- GET /api/sessions - List active sessions
- GET /api/sessions/{id} - Get session details
- POST /api/sessions - Start new session
- POST /api/sessions/{id}/messages - Send message to session
- DELETE /api/sessions/{id} - Stop session

### Fleece Issues
- GET /api/projects/{id}/issues - List issues for project
- GET /api/issues/{id} - Get issue by ID
- POST /api/issues - Create issue
- PUT /api/issues/{id} - Update issue

### Notifications
- POST /api/notifications - Send notification (testing)

## Files to Create

| Path | Purpose |
|------|---------|
| Features/Projects/Controllers/ProjectsController.cs | Projects REST API |
| Features/PullRequests/Controllers/PullRequestsController.cs | PRs REST API |
| Features/Git/Controllers/WorktreesController.cs | Worktrees REST API |
| Features/ClaudeCode/Controllers/SessionsController.cs | Sessions REST API |
| Features/Fleece/Controllers/IssuesController.cs | Issues REST API |

## Files to Modify
- Program.cs - Add Swagger, API explorer

## Implementation Steps
1. Add Swagger/OpenAPI to Program.cs
2. Create ProjectsController (simplest, validates pattern)
3. Implement remaining controllers

## Verification

- Confirm Blazor components still work with @inject

description:
Add bUnit testing for Blazor components to test rendering and component logic without a browser.

## Overview
bUnit enables testing Blazor components in isolation - fast execution, no browser needed, mocks services and verifies rendering.

## Setup

Add bUnit package to existing test project:
```xml
<PackageReference Include="bunit" Version="1.35.9" />
```

## Test Structure

```
tests/Homespun.Tests/
├── Components/
│   ├── ProjectDetailTests.cs
│   ├── PullRequestTreeTests.cs
│   ├── SessionChatTests.cs
│   └── ...
```

## Test Pattern

```csharp
public class ProjectDetailTests : TestContext
{
    [Test]
    public void ProjectDetail_DisplaysProjectName()
    {
        var mockProjectService = new Mock<ProjectService>();
        mockProjectService.Setup(s => s.GetByIdAsync(It.IsAny<string>()))
            .ReturnsAsync(new Project { Id = "1", Name = "Test Project" });

        Services.AddSingleton(mockProjectService.Object);

        var cut = RenderComponent<ProjectDetail>(parameters =>
            parameters.Add(p => p.Id, "1"));

        cut.WaitForAssertion(() =>
            cut.Find("h1").TextContent.Should().Contain("Test Project"));
    }
}
```

The branch and worktree management system needs some improvement as it blocks agents from starting and has become difficult to manage.

## Branches page

- Add a tag to show any worktrees (including main) that are not checked out against the branch that matches the name of the worktree. Add a button to checkout the correct target branch and to get it back on task.

title: Fix session crashes
description:
# Bug Investigation: Playwright MCP Serialization Error Causing Container Crashes

## Summary

The Playwright MCP tools are returning malformed responses that contain .NET type names instead of properly serialized JSON data. This bug appears to be causing container crashes/restarts, with processes being terminated by signals (exit codes 128, 144).

## Evidence

### 1. Malformed Playwright Responses

Instead of returning actual content, Playwright MCP tools return:
```
System.Collections.Generic.List`1[System.Collections.Generic.Dictionary`2[System.String,System.Object]]
```

This occurs across multiple Playwright tools:
- `mcp__playwright__browser_navigate`
- `mcp__playwright__browser_snapshot`
- `mcp__playwright__browser_click`
- `mcp__playwright__browser_take_screenshot`
- `mcp__playwright__browser_press_key`
- `mcp__playwright__browser_close`

### 2. Affected Sessions

Analysis of 11 session logs shows:
- **72+ instances** of this serialization error across 9 session files
- Sessions with Playwright usage have higher rates of abnormal termination
- Sessions end abruptly (USER message as last entry) when Playwright is heavily used

### 3. Exit Codes Indicating Signal Termination

| Exit Code | Meaning | Occurrences |
|-----------|---------|-------------|
| 128 | Process killed by signal | 24 |
| 144 | Signal 16 (SIGUSR1) | 4 |

Exit codes ≥128 indicate the process was terminated by a signal, not a normal exit. This suggests the container runtime (Docker) killed the process, likely due to resource exhaustion.

### 4. Connection Errors Following Playwright Usage

Multiple sessions show `ERR_CONNECTION_REFUSED` errors after Playwright tool calls, indicating the server became unavailable mid-session.

## Your Task

1. **Locate the Playwright MCP implementation** - Find where the MCP server handles Playwright tool responses

2. **Identify the serialization bug** - The code is likely calling `.ToString()` on a `List<Dictionary<string, object>>` instead of properly serializing it to JSON. Look for:
   - Response handling code for Playwright tools
   - JSON serialization of tool results
   - Any place where `List<>` or `Dictionary<>` types are converted to strings

3. **Check for resource leaks** - The repeated malformed responses may indicate:
   - Browser instances not being properly disposed
   - Memory leaks from screenshot/snapshot operations
   - Unclosed connections or streams

4. **Fix the serialization** - Ensure all Playwright tool responses are properly serialized using `System.Text.Json.JsonSerializer.Serialize()` or equivalent, not `.ToString()`

5. **Add error handling** - Ensure Playwright errors don't crash the MCP server:
   - Wrap browser operations in try-catch
   - Properly dispose resources on error
   - Return structured error responses instead of crashing

## Expected vs Actual Behavior

**Expected:** Playwright tools return JSON-serialized content:
```json
{
  "content": [{"type": "text", "text": "Navigation successful"}],
  "isError": false
}
```

**Actual:** Tools return .NET type name as a string:
```
System.Collections.Generic.List`1[System.Collections.Generic.Dictionary`2[System.String,System.Object]]
```

## Files to Investigate

Look for files related to:
- MCP server implementation
- Playwright tool handlers
- Tool response serialization
- Any `IToolHandler` or similar interface implementations

Search patterns:
```bash
# Find Playwright-related MCP code
rg -l "playwright" --type cs
rg -l "mcp.*tool|tool.*handler" --type cs -i

# Find serialization code
rg "List<Dictionary<string" --type cs
rg "ToString\(\)" --type cs -A2 -B2 | grep -i "result\|response\|content"

# Find MCP response building
rg "ToolResult|McpResponse|CallToolResult" --type cs
```

## Reproduction Steps

1. Start a session with Playwright MCP tools enabled
2. Use any Playwright tool (navigate, click, snapshot, etc.)
3. Observe the tool response - it should show the .NET type name instead of actual content
4. After several Playwright operations, the container may crash or become unresponsive

## Success Criteria

- [ ] Playwright tools return properly serialized JSON responses
- [ ] No .NET type names appear in tool output
- [ ] Sessions with heavy Playwright usage complete without abnormal termination
- [ ] Exit codes remain 0 (normal) rather than 128+ (signal-terminated)
- [ ] No `ERR_CONNECTION_REFUSED` errors after Playwright operations

## Additional Context

This bug only started occurring after Playwright MCP tools were introduced. Sessions without Playwright usage do not exhibit the crash behavior. The correlation between Playwright usage and container crashes is strong across all analyzed session logs.

title: Replace ACA session pools with NFS-mounted worker container apps
description:
## Problem

Azure Container Apps session pools do not support volume mounts (confirmed in the 2025-07-01 API). This prevents agent worker containers from sharing a filesystem with the main application container. Currently:

- The Azure Files SMB mount does not support chmod, breaking both Tailscale state and git clone operations
- Agent workers cannot access cloned repositories on the shared filesystem
- Each worker must clone repos independently, duplicating data and bandwidth

The goal is for the main app and all agent containers to mount the same NFS file share and treat repositories as a local filesystem. Agents work in their own git worktrees, minimising file operation conflicts.

## Solution

Replace ACA session pools with regular container apps for agent workers, backed by Azure Files NFS which supports full POSIX permissions. The worker already manages multiple sessions via HTTP API internally (WorkerSessionService), so a single worker container app can handle concurrent sessions without per-session container isolation.

## Work Breakdown

### Phase 1: Infrastructure - VNet + NFS Storage

The ACA environment requires VNet integration at creation time (cannot be added post-creation), and NFS requires the storage account to be accessible from within that VNet.

1. **Add VNet and subnets to Bicep** - Create a new `network.bicep` module:
   - VNet with address space (e.g., 10.0.0.0/16)
   - ACA infrastructure subnet (e.g., 10.0.0.0/23 - ACA requires minimum /23)
   - Storage private endpoint subnet (e.g., 10.0.2.0/24)

2. **Update environment module** (`modules/environment.bicep`):
   - Add `vnetConfiguration` with infrastructure subnet ID
   - Set `internal: true` for internal-only environment (Tailscale handles external access)

3. **Switch storage to NFS** (`modules/storage.bicep`):
   - Change `enabledProtocols` from `'SMB'` to `'NFS'`
   - Set `supportsHttpsTrafficOnly: false` (NFS requires this)
   - Keep `Premium_LRS` / `FileStorage` (already correct tier)

4. **Add private endpoint for storage** - New `storage-endpoint.bicep` module:
   - Create private endpoint for the storage account on the storage subnet
   - Create private DNS zone for `privatelink.file.core.windows.net`
   - Link DNS zone to VNet

5. **Update environment storage mount** (`modules/environment.bicep`):
   - Change from `azureFile` (SMB with account key) to `nfsAzureFile` (NFS, no key needed)
   - NFS uses network-based auth, so `storageAccountKey` parameter can be removed

### Phase 2: Infrastructure - Worker Container App

Replace the session pool module with a regular container app for workers.

6. **Create worker container app module** (`modules/worker-containerapp.bicep`):
   - Regular `Microsoft.App/containerApps` resource (like main app)
   - Mount the same NFS volume from the environment storage
   - Volume mount path: `/data` (same as main app, shared filesystem)
   - Environment variables: GitHub token, Claude OAuth (from Key Vault secrets)
   - Ingress: internal only (only accessible within the ACA environment)
   - Target port: 8080 (worker HTTP API)
   - Scaling: min 1, max based on `maxConcurrentSessions` parameter
   - HTTP scaling rule based on concurrent requests
   - Include `revisionSuffix` with deployment timestamp (same pattern as main app)

7. **Update main.bicep**:
   - Add network module deployment
   - Pass VNet/subnet IDs to environment module
   - Replace session pool module with worker container app module
   - Pass worker container app FQDN as output
   - Remove session pool outputs, add worker app outputs

### Phase 3: Application - Agent Execution Service

The worker already handles multiple sessions via its HTTP API (POST /api/sessions, /api/sessions/{id}/message, etc). The main change is how the main app connects to the worker.

8. **Create new execution service** or update `AzureContainerAppsAgentExecutionService`:
   - Remove all Azure Management API calls for session pool management (no more creating/deleting pool sessions via PUT/DELETE to the sessions API)
   - Configure worker endpoint as a simple base URL (worker container app's internal FQDN)
   - Route all HTTP/SSE calls directly to the worker container app
   - Session lifecycle: worker manages sessions internally (already implemented in WorkerSessionService)
   - StartSession: POST to `http://{worker-fqdn}/api/sessions`
   - SendMessage: POST to `http://{worker-fqdn}/api/sessions/{id}/message`
   - StopSession: DELETE to `http://{worker-fqdn}/api/sessions/{id}`
   - Health check: GET `http://{worker-fqdn}/api/health`

9. **Update configuration** (`AgentExecutionOptions.cs` and `appsettings.json`):
   - Add `WorkerEndpoint` setting (internal FQDN of worker container app)
   - Remove session pool specific settings (SubscriptionId, ResourceGroup, SessionPoolName)
   - Or keep the existing ACA mode and add a new property for the worker endpoint

10. **Update worker to use shared filesystem**:
    - Configure ClaudeAgentSdk working directory to use the NFS-mounted path (e.g., `/data/src/{project}/{worktree}`)
    - Worker already runs in the same filesystem context as main app
    - Verify git operations work on NFS mount (chmod support)

### Phase 4: Cleanup and Testing

11. **Remove session pool resources**:
    - Delete `modules/sessionpool.bicep`
    - Remove session pool references from `main.bicep`
    - Clean up unused parameters

12. **Update deploy script** (`scripts/deploy.ps1`):
    - Update outputs displayed after deployment
    - Add worker container app URL to outputs

13. **Update start.sh**:
    - Revert Tailscale state to `/data/tailscale` (NFS supports chmod)

    - Verify Tailscale connects
    - Start an agent session and confirm it can read/write to shared filesystem
    - Verify concurrent sessions work correctly
    - Test agent worktree isolation

## Key Decisions

- **Single worker container app** vs per-session containers: Single app is simpler, the worker already handles multi-session. Agents are isolated via git worktrees, not containers.
- **ACA environment recreation**: VNet integration requires recreating the environment. This will cause downtime. Plan for a maintenance window.
- **Internal ingress only**: Both main app and worker use internal ingress. Tailscale provides external access to the main app. Workers are only accessible within the environment.

title: Optimize Docker build times with shared base image
description:
Both Docker images (Dockerfile and src/Homespun.AgentWorker/Dockerfile) install nearly identical runtime tooling independently - Node.js, gh CLI, Claude Code, Playwright MCP + Chromium, Fleece CLI, Docker CLI. These npm global installs (especially Claude Code with node-pty native compilation, and Playwright MCP + Chromium at ~1GB) are the primary bottleneck. Every code change rebuilds all of this from scratch. The CI/CD pipeline (cd.yml) also has zero caching configured.

Approach: Shared Base Image + CI Caching

1. Create Dockerfile.base - shared tooling image with all common runtime tools (.NET 10 SDK, Node.js, gh CLI, Claude Code, Playwright MCP + Chromium, Fleece CLI, Docker CLI). Use BuildKit cache mounts on npm install steps.

2. Modify Dockerfile - change runtime stage FROM to use base image. Keep only main-app-specific items (Tailscale, user setup, published app copy).

3. Modify src/Homespun.AgentWorker/Dockerfile - same pattern, keep only worker-specific items.

4. Update scripts/run.sh - build base image first before app builds. Docker layer cache makes this instant when base unchanged.

5. Update scripts/run.ps1 - same change for PowerShell.

6. Update .github/workflows/cd.yml - add BuildKit (setup-buildx-action), add build-base-image job, use registry cache (cache-from/cache-to), upgrade build-push-action to v6.

Files to modify: Dockerfile.base (new), Dockerfile, src/Homespun.AgentWorker/Dockerfile, scripts/run.sh, scripts/run.ps1, .github/workflows/cd.yml

Expected impact: Local code-only rebuild ~2-5 min (from ~15-20 min). CI builds with cache hit ~5-8 min (from ~20-30 min). Disk savings ~2.5GB shared vs ~5.5GB duplicated.

title: Create Homespun.Server ASP.NET minimal API project
description:
Create the new `Homespun.Server` project that will be the ASP.NET backend, hosting all server-side logic, API endpoints, and SignalR hubs. This project replaces the current `Homespun` web project's backend role.

## What to create

### Project setup
- Create `src/Homespun.Server/Homespun.Server.csproj` as a `Microsoft.NET.Sdk.Web` project targeting `net10.0`
- Add to `Homespun.sln` under the `src` solution folder
- Add ProjectReference to `Homespun.Shared` and `Homespun.ClaudeAgentSdk`
- Add NuGet references: `Fleece.Core`, `Markdig`, `Microsoft.AspNetCore.SignalR.Client`, `Microsoft.Data.Sqlite`, `Octokit`, `Swashbuckle.AspNetCore`

### What goes in this project

**Program.cs** - New minimal API startup:
- All DI service registration (from current Program.cs lines 21-260)
- Configure CORS to allow the Blazor WASM client origin
- Map all API controllers
- Map SignalR hubs (`/hubs/notifications`, `/hubs/claudecode`)
- Map health check endpoint
- Serve the Blazor WASM client as static files (via `app.UseBlazorFrameworkFiles()` and `app.MapFallbackToFile("index.html")`)
- Swagger/OpenAPI configuration
- Data protection configuration
- Mock mode support

**Controllers** - Move all 7+ API controllers as-is:
- `SessionsController`
- `ProjectsController`
- `PullRequestsController`
- `WorktreesController`
- `IssuesController`
- `NotificationsController`
- `OrchestrationController`

**SignalR Hubs** - Move both hubs:
- `ClaudeCodeHub` → Implement `IClaudeCodeHubClient` from Shared
- `NotificationHub`

**All Feature Services** - Move complete Features/ directory structure:
- ClaudeCode services (ClaudeSessionService, AgentExecutionService, etc.)
- Git services (GitWorktreeService, MergeStatusCacheService, etc.)
- GitHub services (GitHubService, GitHubClientWrapper, etc.)
- Fleece services (FleeceService, FleeceIssueTransitionService, etc.)
- Gitgraph services (GraphService, GraphCacheService, etc.)
- Projects services (ProjectService)
- PullRequests services (PullRequestWorkflowService, PullRequestDataService)
- Notifications services (NotificationService)
- AgentOrchestration services (MiniPromptService, BranchIdGeneratorService)
- Commands (CommandRunner)
- Testing/Mock services
- Shared services (MarkdownRenderingService)

**Data layer** - Move all data access:
- `JsonDataStore` and `IDataStore`
- `MessageCacheStore`, `SessionMetadataStore`, `ClaudeSessionStore`
- All data file I/O

**Configuration** - Move:
- `appsettings.json`, `appsettings.Mock.json`
- `launchSettings.json`
- `start.sh` (container entrypoint)

## Agent execution and Homespun.Worker integration
- Agent execution services in the server orchestrate work by communicating with the **Homespun.Worker** (TypeScript/Hono) containers via HTTP
- The server does NOT run Claude Code sessions directly — it delegates to Homespun.Worker containers that use the official `@anthropic-ai/claude-agent-sdk` TypeScript SDK
- `DockerAgentExecutionService` spawns Homespun.Worker containers and communicates via HTTP/SSE
- `AzureContainerAppsAgentExecutionService` manages Homespun.Worker instances on Azure
- The `Homespun.ClaudeAgentSdk` C# library provides the SDK client interface used by the server to interact with Workers

## Key decisions
- The server project does NOT contain Blazor components or Razor pages
- No `AddRazorComponents()` call - this is a pure API server
- CORS must be configured to allow the WASM client to make requests
- The server hosts the WASM client's files via `UseBlazorFrameworkFiles()`/`MapFallbackToFile`
- Service interfaces that the client needs (for strongly-typed HTTP clients) should reference types from Homespun.Shared only
- No reference to Homespun.Worker is needed in the .csproj — communication is over HTTP at runtime

- All API endpoints are accessible via Swagger
- SignalR hubs accept connections
- Health check endpoint works

- `Home.razor` - Dashboard
- `Projects.razor` - Project list
- `ProjectDetail.razor` - Project detail with sessions, issues, PRs
- `ProjectCreate.razor` - Create new project
- `ProjectEdit.razor` - Edit project settings
- `FeatureCreate.razor` - Create feature/PR
- `IssueEdit.razor` - Edit issue details
- `SessionManagement.razor` - View/manage Claude sessions
- `AgentPrompts.razor` - Manage agent prompts
- `Settings.razor` - Application settings
- `Error.razor` - Error page
- `NotFound.razor` - 404 page

### Shared Components (50+)
Move all from `Components/Shared/` to `Homespun.Client/Components/`:

**Chat UI components:**
- `ChatInput.razor`, `ChatMessage.razor`, `ProcessingIndicator.razor`
- `TextBlock.razor`, `ThinkingBlock.razor`, `ToolUseBlock.razor`, `ToolResultBlock.razor`
- `ContentBlock.razor`

**Panel components:**
- `AgentControlPanel.razor`, `AgentManagementPanel.razor`, `AgentStatusPanel.razor`
- `WorktreeManagementPanel.razor`, `CurrentPullRequestDetailPanel.razor`
- `IssueDetailPanel.razor`

**Utility components:**
- `Modal.razor`, `ConfirmModal.razor`, `LoadingSpinner.razor`
- `NotificationBanner.razor`, `FormMessage.razor`, `AsyncActionButton.razor`

**Session history components:**
- `SessionHistoryList.razor`, `SessionCacheHistory.razor`

### Design showcase (optional - lower priority)
- `Design/DesignShowcase.razor` and all showcase components
- Can be migrated later or dropped

## Key changes per component

### Remove render mode directives
Every component currently has `@rendermode InteractiveServer`. Remove ALL of these - WASM components don't use rendermode.

### Replace service injection
Before (Blazor Server - direct service injection):
```razor
@inject IProjectService ProjectService
@code {
    var projects = await ProjectService.GetAllAsync();
}
```

After (Blazor WASM - HTTP service):
```razor
@inject HttpProjectApiService ProjectApi
@code {
    var projects = await ProjectApi.GetAllProjectsAsync();
}
```

### Common patterns to change:
1. **`@inject IProjectService`** → `@inject HttpProjectApiService`
2. **`@inject IClaudeSessionService`** → `@inject HttpSessionApiService` (for REST calls) + `@inject SignalRSessionService` (for real-time)
3. **`@inject IGitWorktreeService`** → `@inject HttpWorktreeApiService`
4. **`@inject IFleeceService`** → `@inject HttpIssueApiService`
5. **`@inject IGitHubService`** → HTTP service or data passed via API
6. **`@inject INotificationService`** → `@inject HttpNotificationApiService` + SignalR for real-time
7. **`@inject NavigationManager`** → Keep as-is (works in WASM)
8. **`@inject IGraphService`** → `@inject HttpGraphApiService`

### Handle services that don't have API equivalents
Some services currently injected by components may not have corresponding API endpoints. For each:
- If the data is needed: Add a new API endpoint on the server and a client HTTP service
- If it's purely client-side logic: Reimplement in the client project
- Examples:
  - `IBreadcrumbService` → Reimplement client-side (it just tracks navigation)
  - `IMarkdownRenderingService` → Can run client-side in WASM (Markdig works in WASM)
  - `ISignalRUrlProvider` → Not needed; client connects directly

## Static assets
- Move `wwwroot/` contents to `Homespun.Client/wwwroot/`
- Move `package.json` and Tailwind config to client project
- Move `.razor.css` scoped style files alongside their components

## _Imports.razor

```razor
@using System.Net.Http.Json
@using Microsoft.AspNetCore.Components.Forms
@using Microsoft.AspNetCore.Components.Routing
@using Microsoft.AspNetCore.Components.Web
@using Microsoft.AspNetCore.Components.WebAssembly.Http

@using Homespun.Shared.Models.Git
@using Homespun.Shared.Models.Notifications
@using Homespun.Client.Layout
@using Homespun.Client.Components
@using Homespun.Client.Services
```

- Pages render correctly when served via the Server project

description:
Update the Docker build, startup scripts, and CI/CD workflows to work with the new multi-project architecture (Homespun.Server, Homespun.Client, Homespun.Shared) and the existing Homespun.Worker (TypeScript/Hono).

## Dockerfile changes

### Current Dockerfile
The current Dockerfile builds a single `Homespun` project. It needs to be updated to:

1. **Build the WASM client** → produces static files
2. **Build the server** → produces the API server binary
3. **Package them together** → server serves the WASM client files

### New multi-stage Dockerfile
\`\`\`dockerfile
# Stage 1: Build
FROM mcr.microsoft.com/dotnet/sdk:10.0 AS build
WORKDIR /src

# Install Node.js for Tailwind CSS build (client project)
RUN apt-get update && apt-get install -y nodejs npm

# Copy solution and project files
COPY Homespun.sln .
COPY src/Homespun.Shared/Homespun.Shared.csproj src/Homespun.Shared/
COPY src/Homespun.Server/Homespun.Server.csproj src/Homespun.Server/
COPY src/Homespun.Client/Homespun.Client.csproj src/Homespun.Client/
COPY src/Homespun.ClaudeAgentSdk/Homespun.ClaudeAgentSdk.csproj src/Homespun.ClaudeAgentSdk/

# Restore
RUN dotnet restore

# Copy everything and build
COPY . .

# Build Tailwind CSS (in client project)
WORKDIR /src/src/Homespun.Client
RUN npm install && npm run css:build

# Publish server (which includes WASM client via ProjectReference)
WORKDIR /src
RUN dotnet publish src/Homespun.Server/Homespun.Server.csproj -c Release -o /app/publish

# Stage 2: Runtime
FROM ${BASE_IMAGE} AS final
WORKDIR /app
COPY --from=build /app/publish .
ENTRYPOINT ["dotnet", "Homespun.Server.dll"]
\`\`\`

### Key points
- The Server .csproj should have a ProjectReference to the Client project so `dotnet publish` automatically includes WASM output
- Server .csproj needs: `<ProjectReference Include="../Homespun.Client/Homespun.Client.csproj" />` (or use the `Microsoft.AspNetCore.Components.WebAssembly.Server` package approach)
- The published output should contain both the server DLL and the `wwwroot/_framework/` directory with WASM files
- **Homespun.Worker** (TypeScript/Hono) has its own separate Dockerfile (`src/Homespun.Worker/Dockerfile`) and builds independently — it is NOT part of the .NET server build

### cd.yml (CD pipeline)

- `Homespun.Worker` (TypeScript) is referenced in the solution for IDE convenience but is not a .csproj project
- Update solution folder nesting

title: Remove watchtower
description: Remove watchtower from all build scripts and container build - it's not required anymore as we will be using Azure Container Apps for most of the production deployment.

title: Agents aren't being started with issue template variables replaced
description: When an agent is staretd on an issue, the template comes in with {{title}} text rather than the actual injected titles. Ensure that these are injected with template variables replaced when the prompt is being sent to the agent worker.

title: Fleece is not installed on the worker containers
description: Ensure the Fleece CLI tool is installed on the worker containers. This can be done with `dotnet tool install -g Fleece.Cli`. It is installed on the parent application containers, just not on the agent worker containers.

title: Dotnet is not installed on the worker containers
description: Ensure that the dotnet CLI is installed on the worker containers, including .NET SDKs 8, 9 and 10. This used to be done by having the image based on the dotnet SDK base image (similar to the main container image), but now we are working off the node image due to the Typescript SDK.

title: Permissions are not being passed to agent per command
description: Changing the permissions in the UI and sending a new message to Claude does not change the permissions of the agent. This should be updated such that new permissions are sent and the Claude Code server should use new permissions per message (if they change). The "build" permission that is used to start agents should refer to "bypass permissions".

title: Pass all messages from server to client
description: Currently messages are only persisted on the client when they are sent over SignalR, and refreshing a page can lose messages. Instead, these messages should be stored on the server (in memory or using the JSONL serialisation if that still exists) and the client should be able to perform a full refresh of all messages from the server. This should only happen if the use enters a page that is currently midway through processing. It should start by showing the messages as they stream in, with a button at the top of the conversation that prompts the user to load all previous messages in from the server.

title: "Starting session" doesn't refresh after session is started
description: When a new agent is started the "starting session" button goes into a "loading" state. Even though the timeline shows the session has started the page must be refreshed for the button to disappear and show the "open chat" page. Review this - once the agent has been started the state of this button and the issue properties panel should change.

title: Answer and plan tools no longer work correctly
description:
The answer and plan tools for the application no longer work correctly when run in docker agent execution mode. In this mode, when the agent uses the AskUserQuestion tool the agent should stop and wait for the user to respond. It is currently assuming that the first answer provided is the correct one and proceeding anyway. This is required only for the local execution mode as in the local execution mode the instance of Claude Code by default will just continue execution.

However, we are using the Typescript version of the Claude Agent SDK in Docker and Azure Container Apps execution modes, which allows this flow. Refer to https://platform.claude.com/docs/en/agent-sdk/typescript#ask-user-question and https://platform.claude.com/docs/en/agent-sdk/user-input#handle-clarifying-questions for information on how the SDK handles clarifying questions.

Plans operate somewhat differently. Review the code and documentation and see if you can come up with a plan to fix this behaviour for the Docker and Agent Execution modes. The SDK has recently been changed to V1, so this may be fixed or it may require minor updates to the code.

If it will simplify things, OK to remove specific handling for questions and tools from the Local execution mode. Otherwise, if they are handled separately and don't interact in the different modes then OK to leave it as is.

title: CurrentPullRequestDetailPanel doesn't refresh session status via SignalR
description:
The CurrentPullRequestDetailPanel component displays session status but does not subscribe to SignalR events (SessionStarted, SessionStatusChanged, SessionStopped). The session status badge will show stale data after session state changes on the server. Users must navigate away and back to see the current state.

This is the same bug pattern that was fixed in IssueDetailPanel (PR #222).

Fix: Add SignalR subscription following the IssueDetailPanel.razor pattern:
1. Add @implements IAsyncDisposable
2. Declare private HubConnection? _hubConnection
3. Call SetupSignalRConnectionAsync() from OnInitializedAsync()
4. Subscribe to SessionStarted, SessionStatusChanged, SessionStopped events
5. Implement proper DisposeAsync() cleanup

title: AgentManagementPanel doesn't refresh session list via SignalR
description:
The AgentManagementPanel component (displayed on /sessions page) shows a list of active sessions with status badges and uptime, but does not subscribe to SignalR events. The session list won't show live status updates - users must refresh the page to see new agent statuses or when sessions stop.

Issues:
- Does NOT implement IAsyncDisposable
- Does NOT have SignalR subscription
- Status indicators and uptime calculations become stale
- New sessions won't appear without refresh

This is the same bug pattern that was fixed in IssueDetailPanel (PR #222).

Fix: Add SignalR subscription and refresh the sessions list when events are received.
